paper_metadata.title: Evaluating BRAC's Targeting the Ultra-Poor Program: Effects on Children's Time Allocation, Economic Preferences, and Women's Empowerment

component_a_cash_support.cash_evidence_citation: Under both support packages, the program provides training, a consumption subsidy, and some inputs to maintain the income-generating activities

component_b_assets.assets_evidence_citation: BRAC is the pioneer of the transfer program also known as graduation program that targets those who are living below the poverty line, includes direct transfers of income generating livestock assets/loan and livelihood training

study_characteristics.outcomes_evidence_citation: These impacts may be in the form of changes in (i) children's time allocation to education and income-generating activities, (ii) own preferences that matter for economic decision-making, and (iii) the control of intrahousehold decision-making, self-esteem and self-confidence
study_characteristics.design_evidence_citation: Using data from multiple waves of a Randomized Controlled Trial

evidence_citations.program_name_citation: this thesis estimates the effect of BRAC's "Targeting the Ultra-Poor" -an anti-poverty program involving asset and credit transfers
evidence_citations.country_citation: Since independence, Bangladesh has made remarkable progress in reducing abject poverty and achieved the status of a lower-middleincome country
evidence_citations.target_population_citation: Since the program is targeted to the main female of the household, it could potentially affect the economic and behavioural outcomes for both the recipients and their children
